message_1: A sample of uranium-238 has an initial activity level of 5.0 becquerels. If the half-life of uranium-238 is 4.5 billion years, how many becquerels of activity will remain after 9.0 billion years?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the radioactive decay formula:

A = A₀ * (1/2)^(t/T)

where:
A = the final activity level (in becquerels)
A₀ = the initial activity level (in becquerels)
t = the time elapsed (in years)
T = the half-life of the substance (in years)

Given:
A₀ = 5.0 becquerels
t = 9.0 billion years
T = 4.5 billion years

We can now plug these values into the formula:

A = 5.0 * (1/2)^(9.0 / 4.5)

A = 5.0 * (1/2)^2

A = 5.0 * (1/4)

A = 5.0 * 0.25

A = 1.25 becquerels

After 9.0 billion years, the activity level of the uranium-238 sample will be 1.25 becquerels.
